tit.e: Kosode no te (the hand of kosode [short sleeved kimono])

sen.j: 小袖の手（こそでのて）は、鳥山石燕の妖怪画集『今昔百鬼拾遺』にある日本の妖怪。
sen.e: Kosode no te is a Japanese specter which is drawn in "Konjaku Hyakki Shui" (Ancient and Modern Gleanings of the Hundred Demons), a collection of specters illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA.

Kosode no te (literally, the hand of kosode [short sleeved kimono]) is one of Japanese yokai (monsters, spirits, ghosts and specters) which is drawn in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book "Konjaku Hyakki Shui" (Supplement to The Hundred Demons from the Present and the Past).

sen.j: 小袖（袖口の狭い高級な和服）の袖から女性の幽霊の手が伸びたものが小袖の手である。
sen.e: A female ghost's arm stretches out from a sleeve of kosode (high-class Japanese clothes with narrow-wrist sleeves); this is kosode no te.
A female ghost's hand and arm stretching out from a sleeve of kosode (high-class kimono with narrow-wrist sleeves) is the kosode no te.

sen.j: 本来、死んだ人間の小袖は形見の品となったり、寺に納められて供養されるはずが、高級な小袖が売却され、成仏できない霊がその小袖に取り憑いたものが小袖の手とされる。
sen.e: Properly, kosode of a dead person was inherited as a memento, or offered to the temple asking them to pray for the owner's soul; however, high-class kosode was sold off and possessed by a ghost who had failed to become Buddha; thus Kosode no te came into being.

sen.e: Sometime during Keicho era (1596-1615), a man lived in Kyoto, called Shichizaemon MATSUYA, bought kimono at a secondhand clothes store for his daughter.
